children.value: Sinusoids, Phasors, Phasor Relationship for circuit elements Impedance and Admittance. Impedance Combinations.
Sinusoids : A signal that has the form of the sine or cosine function.

Alternating Current driven by Sinusodial current or voltage sources
level
Sinusodial signal is easy to generate and transmit.
Fourier analysis: any periodic signal can be represented by a sum of sinusoids.
Easy to handle mathematically (derivative of sine, derivative of cosine)

\begin{aligned}
\sin(\omega t \pm 180) &= - \sin(\omega t) \\
\cos(\omega t \pm 180) &= - \cos(\omega t) \\
\sin(\omega t \pm 90) &= \pm \cos(\omega t) \\
\cos(\omega t \pm 90) &= \mp \sin(\omega t) \\
A\cos(\omega t) + B\sin(\omega t) &= C\cos(\omega t - \theta) \\
C = \sqrt(A^2 + B^2)&, \theta = \tan^-1(\frac{B}{A]})

\end{aligned}
Find phase angle between two sinusoids

State shich sinusoid is leading
Steps:
Make two signals the same form
z = x + jy = r \angle \phi = r(\cos\phi + j\sin\phi)
V(t) = V_m \cos(\omega t + \phi) = Re(V_me^{j(\omega t + \phi)}) = Re(V_me^{j\phi}e^{j\omega t})
*** In our class, we define phasor fo cosine function
v = L\frac{di}{dt} = -\omega LI_m\sin(\omega t + \phi) = \omega LI_m cos(\omega t + \phi + 90\degree)
